items.title: comparison to pystatsd
items.body:
this project seems more active than pystatsd (https://github.com/jsocol/pystatsd), though both have very similar feature sets.

can you explain why one would choose one over the other? thanks! :)

items.title: not compatible with latest python-statsd
items.body:
connection defined via python-statsd Connection object.

Excrept of the error:
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/wsgi_statsd/**init**.py", line 101, in send_stats
    timer = self.statsd_client.timer(key_name)
AttributeError: 'Client' object has no attribute 'timer'

items.title: Timer context manager doesn't add ".total"
items.body:
https://github.com/WoLpH/python-statsd/blob/master/statsd/timer.py
Is there any purpose on and logic behind why `Timer.time` context manager does not add `.total.` into the metric name but `Timer.stop()` call adds it by default? It seems inconsistent.

items.title: Exclude 'tests' from install targets
items.body:
Currently, the distribution tries to install the tests as well. This is a problem when using a package manager like portage that complains due to possible (or actual) file collisions.

It can be excluded by changing setup.py:
- packages=setuptools.find_packages(),
  +packages=setuptools.find_packages(exclude=('tests',)),

items.title: support for connecting to statsd via tcp
items.body:
Statsd can be configured to accept messages over tcp (instead of udp)

Would this be easy to add?

items.title: Raw metric is pretty unusable
items.body:
We've just started using Raw metrics, but it seems it's pretty unusable. 

I've made an issue report against statsd: https://github.com/etsy/statsd/issues/467

But so far it seems like tha statsd accepts only rate as the third element, not timestamp of any kind.

I even had a problem finding the Raw issue mentioned anywhere outside of python-statsd or statsd itself

items.title: Bad commit for 0ms timing....
items.body:
I would probably revert https://github.com/WoLpH/python-statsd/pull/31

I sincerely apologize.. this needed to be fixes upstream of the lib.

items.title: Why is setup_requires=['nose', 'mock', 'coverage'] needed?
items.body:
I ask because I ran into issues while trying to install python-statsd through a proxy. e.g.,  ('pip install --proxy myproxy.net:80 python-statsd'). The install fails because its unable to download the setup_requires packages. If I remove the 'setup_requires', install succeeds. 

Still trying to figure out the issue. Seems to be related with _setuptools/ssl_support.py(184)https_open()_ though.

So the root cause of my install problem is not the _setup_requires=['nose', 'mock', 'coverage']_ line, but it made me wonder why this is even needed since these are test dependency modules. Are they needed for the package to function? If it's just for tests, should they be in _tests_require_?

items.title: Can't disable metrics on the new StatsClient
items.body:
I am attempting to use a feature I helped implement a few months ago in the `Connection` class that would allow to pass in a `disabled=True` argument.

This class is still referenced in the `README` file (along with the explanation on how to use the argument) but I can't seem to use it with the new `StatsClient` class.

items.title: Small time deltas are swallowed up by formatting
items.body: I'm trying to measure the time of the invocations of small functions.  The format for timers has my actual times as <1ms, so it's sending 0|ms.  For my own use I'm sending %0.08f as the format for timers in that particular virtualenv so my problem isn't urgent, but I'd like to know if you've thought about this, e.g. passing in a format string for the timer so that the scale can be set by the caller?

items.title: please tag v1.5.8 in github
items.body:
Pypi list v1.5.8 : https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-statsd

Seems you forgot to tag it in github :-]

items.title: please add License / Copying information
items.body:
Hello,

According to the pypi page at https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-statsd this software is released under a BSD license.  Would you be kind enough to add a copy of the license in the git source code as well as the copyright information?  Thank you!

items.title: Multi-Metric packets
items.body:
Hello,

Are you interested in supporting the multi-metric-packets functionality as described here:
https://github.com/etsy/statsd/#multi-metric-packets

We are concerned with sending too many packets from our python applications.

I'd be happy to implement it and send a pull, just figured I'd ask if you don't support it for a reason.

items.title: statsd.raw.Raw: send should accept datetime objects
items.body:
> > > import calendar
> > > from datetime import datetime
> > > dt = datetime.utcnow()
> > > r.send('Test', 23, calendar.timegm(dt.timetuple()))

I'd like the raw.send(value, unix_time) method to also accept & convert datetime objects. The code above does this externally.

items.title: Naming on metrics is not consistent
items.body:
I am not sure if this is a problem with how python-statsd is sending its data or how StatsD is processing and relaying to graphite, but there is some inconsistency that makes it hard to maintain a naming convention when sending metrics over.

For example, for counters, if we use a "my_counter" name, it displays like this on Graphite:

```
Graphite
`-- stats
    `-- my_counter
```

But for gauges or timers, they would add a prepending name depending on the name of the metric. So the above example will end up looking like this:

```
Graphite
`-- stats
    |-- timers
    |   |-- my_timer
    |-- gauges
    |   |-- my_gauge
    `-- my_counter
```

So timers and gauges prepend their name, but counters do not. If we try to use a naming convention (e.g. server name) it would be difficult to try and keep an order because of this.

I wasn't able to effectively find out what is missing here, but as far as I can tell python-statsd is sending the information correctly, without mangling the names we use.

Any ideas?

items.title: Turning service OFF
items.body:
There is currently no way to turn this service OFF. Given that I have a need for multiple different environments, some of them should be turned OFF.

The way I am currently approaching this right now is by setting bogus values to the Connection object so that metrics are not firing to the right place.

This is far from optimal, and I would ideally like to set a flag to the Connection class that turns ON/OFF the service (ON by default).

If this is accepted as an issue, I can have a pull request ready by the end of the day with tests and docs :)

items.title: Released version has packaging problems
items.body:
The most recent version released to PyPi (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-statsd/1.5.4) has all kinds of issues, mainly it contains files with "BACKUP", "LOCAL" and "REMOTE" in them with what it looks like unresolved merges.

This is the output when installing (it does manage to install):

```

Downloading/unpacking python-statsd

    zip_safe flag not set; analyzing archive contents...

    Installed /Users/adeza/tmp/build/python-statsd/mock-0.7.2-py2.6.egg

    Installed /Users/adeza/tmp/build/python-statsd/nose-1.1.2-py2.6.egg

```

And here is the output of the installed files:

```
__init__.py                  __init__.py.BASE.27580.pyc   __init__.py.REMOTE.27580.py  average.py                   client.pyc                   counter.py                   gauge.pyc                    timer.py
```

items.title: "total" appended as subname when using timer decorator
items.body:
I do something like

``` python
t = statsd.Timer("MyApp")
@t.decorate("function"):
def f():
   ...

```

I want to send "MyApp.function: 100|ms" 
Instead,"MyApp.function.total: 100|ms" is sent. with no way to remove the total

Looking at the source, I don't see an easy way to change this. Thoughts?

items.title: Version bump on pypi.python.org
items.body: Could you please bump the version and update the library on PyPI to include the recent Timer.decorate fix?

items.title: Gauges take arbitrary values, not just integers.
items.body:
From https://github.com/etsy/statsd/blob/bf62f646d195f08fb17a37f7352be47366b2eaa9/stats.js#L120, any decimal/floating point number can be stored in a gauge by statsd. However, https://github.com/WoLpH/python-statsd/blob/master/statsd/gauge.py#L18 sends only an integer.

Example code:

```
from decimal import Decimal
import mock
import statsd

with mock.patch('statsd.Client') as mock_client:
    instance = mock_client.return_value
    instance._send.return_value = 1

    gauge = statsd.Gauge('testing')
    gauge.send('', 10.5)
    mock_client._send.assert_called_with(mock.ANY, {'testing': '10.5|g'}) # Actually sends '10|g'

    gauge.send('', Decimal('6.576'))
    mock_client._send.assert_called_with(mock.ANY, {'testing': '6.576|g'}) # Actually sends '6|g'

    gauge('', 1)
    mock_client._send.assert_called_with(mock.ANY, {'testing': '1|g'}) # Correctly sends '1|g'
```

items.title: Publish recent version 1.4.2 to pypi.python.org
items.body: Could you please publish recent version to pypi, as http://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-statsd still have 1.4.1
